pageContext.claim: “And [the European car companies are] all pouring cars into our country and we don't -- essentially, don't tax them. It's 2-1/2 percent but for the most part, they don't pay.”
pageContext.analysis: There's no indication that European car companies don't pay the tariff to import cars to the U.S. German automakers sold 1.35 million vehicles in the United States in 2017, about 8 percent of total US car sales. Of those, only 494,000 were exported from Germany to the United States — 25 percent less than in 2013, according to the German carmakers association.The U.S. and E.U. were working toward a deal to eliminate these tariffs but negotiations stalled before Trump took office. Plus, he's neglecting to mention the U.S. has a 25 percent tariff as a result of a trade dispute over chickens.
